comments.body:
Creating a checklist of what we have applied currently. (Note: What Datacite has made recommended or optional can be mandatory for us locally. I will bold the properties that are mandatory for us.)

#### Datacite Mandatory
- [x] **1 Identifier** (This is the ORCID ID and will be visible to users)
- [x]  **1.a identifierType** (This is ORCID and will not be visible to users)
- [x] **2 Creator** (The depositor can make additional creator fields to enter multiple creators)
- [x] **2.1 creatorName** (This information is what becomes visible in the "Creator(s)" field)
- [x] **3 Title** (This is visible to users)
- [x] **4 Publisher** (This is visible to users and defaults to Princeton University. It may be manually changed)
- [x] **5 PublicationYear**
- [ ] **10 ResourceType**
- [ ] **10.a resourceTypeGeneral**

#### Datacite Recommended or Optional
- [ ] 11 AlternateIdentifier
- [ ] 11.a alternateIdentifierType
- [ ] 12 RelatedIdentifier
- [ ] 12.a relatedIdentifierType
- [ ] 12.b relationType
- [ ] 15 Version
- [x] **16 Rights**
- [x] **17 Description**
- [x] **17.a descriptionType**
- [ ] 19 FundingReference
- [ ] 19.1 funderName
- [ ] 19.3 awardNumber
- [ ] 19.3.a awardURI
- [ ] 20 RelatedItem
- [ ] 20.a relatedItemType
- [ ] 20.b relationType

I have created a draft of [wireframes for the metadata](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1iddiW0nhZahKxdDRzWAthiF_Y1di2_88b5XUr9AtBDQ/edit#slide=id.gfebb5c6012_0_58)

HH to-do

- [x] Create (working) wireframes for metadata fields
- [ ] Obtain feedback from RDSS
- [ ] Obtain feedabck from PRDS
- [ ] Revise as needed to complete

comments.body: I tested this in staging and it works as intended, with one caveat: if a collection has some items with remote metadata and some items without, the bulk edit will fail when it tries to update remote metadata for the items that don't have it. @kelea99 and I talked about this and agreed it's probably fine because collections typically all have remote metadata or none of them do.

comments.body:
Way to get out ahead of things, @kayiwa!

I've done a quick audit, and there are a lot of task `name:` lines with the word "include" in them, and a lot of READMEs that feature the text "to include contact information", and a lot of config files or templates with the word "include" in them, plus a few variables called "include", but very few bare `include` Ansible directives - most already use `include_tasks` or `include_role` or `include_vars`. PR coming for the remaining few.
This is what I get for not running the tests locally ðŸ˜ž.

pulfalight.title: Add location info in addition to repository -- for some users, location is more important than repository

comments.body:
Adding the breadcrumb seems straightforward.

For the other recommendation, do you mean adding a caption to the image at the top of the collection page? (see screenshot)
![Screen Shot 2022-09-13 at 10.27.44 AM.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5cba1f45fec3b63424e0f761/d74c6874-7cae-44e8-9c0e-af421f346299)

Shown here is the "Access & Use" tab, which links to https://findingaids.princeton.edu/repositories/univarchives -- Should the image at the top also link there? It currently is not a link. 

For a caption, it might look best right under the title. Maybe wording like "Access this collection at X library"?

I think having the image as a link to access and use makes alot of sense.
And the caption works too.
@ccleeton make the image a link to the "access and use" tab? Or a link to the repositories page (e.g. https://findingaids.princeton.edu/repositories/univarchives)?
I think the access and use is more helpful since it includes potential restrictions or if parts are housed off site

Should we see if we can add the "visit us" link to the access and use tab, and then have the image link to that tab, and not add a caption at all?

for the additional breadcrumb in the search results -- should this also link to the "access and use" tab for the collection?

I'd like to see the visit us link added to the tab but I'd like to see the caption added so users don't have to click it if they don't need or want to.

For the breadcrumb i would say yes to link the access and use to be consistent

Okay and you definitely want the caption to link to the Visit Us page? Sorry for all the back and forth; I just want to make sure in that context you're not concerned about the potential restrictions or if parts are housed off site. Thank you!

Another option instead of a caption by the collection title might be to repeat the breadcrumb somewhere on the page. Perhaps above the component title? See screenshot:

![Screen Shot 2022-09-13 at 11 51 42 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/845363/189948421-ef7facec-be76-46b6-baeb-044b19285cd1.png)

Then I guess it would also link to the "access and use" tab.
I love this breadcrumb idea, more than a caption by the photo. Would it all be clickable?
I think it would all be clickable the same way it is in a search result.

So this proposal is:

* Add the storage note to the "Access & Use" tab. Still keep it on the "Collection Overview" tab.
* Add the library before the other breadcrumbs; if clicked it takes you to the "Access & Use" tab of the collection show page.
* Add breadcrumbs to the top each component content area, above the component title. functionality the same as the breadcrumb on the search results page.
* Make the library image next to the collection title a clickable link that goes to the repository page (e.g. https://findingaids.princeton.edu/repositories/univarchives).
* Add a link to the "Visit Us" page on the "Access & Use" tab

I'm curious what @sdellis thinks of this proposal.

@ccleeton I'm just confirming that you're talking about the "Your Account" login in the main navigation bar, correct? It appears to be linked to that address in all other instances I can see, but I agree that linking to the Aeon login makes much more sense.
